newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Beetles assail Caravaggio masterpiece in Dublin.
newsitem.headline: Beetles assail Caravaggio masterpiece in Dublin.

text.p: Beetles with a taste for glue have forced Ireland's National Museum to take down a priceless painting by the Italian baroque artist Caravaggio.
"Last week we inspected the painting after reports that beetles were seen flying around it," the Director of the museum, Raymond Kevany told Irish radio.

"There were indeed insects on the back of the painting which turned out to be biscuit beetles which have an appetite for glue." So the "Taking of Christ," was taken down for a while to remove the infestation.
The painting hung unnoticed for decades in a Jesuit house in Dublin until a member of the gallery visited it and recognised it was a work by Caravaggio, who died in 1610 at the age of 37.
The Order later gave the painting to the museum where it has been acclaimed as one of the artist's finest works.
